41/**
42 * DOC: dp helpers
43 *
44 * These functions contain some common logic and helpers at various abstraction
45 * levels to deal with Display Port sink devices and related things like DP aux
46 * channel transfers, EDID reading over DP aux channels, decoding certain DPCD
47 * blocks, ...
48 */
49
50/* Helpers for DP link training */
51static u8 dp_link_status(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE], int r)
52{
53 return link_status[r - DP_LANE0_1_STATUS];
54}
55
56static u8 dp_get_lane_status(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE],
57 int lane)
58{
59 int i = DP_LANE0_1_STATUS + (lane >> 1);
60 int s = (lane & 1) * 4;
61 u8 l = dp_link_status(link_status, i);
62 return (l >> s) & 0xf;
63}
64
65bool drm_dp_channel_eq_ok(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE],
66 int lane_count)
67{
68 u8 lane_align;
69 u8 lane_status;
70 int lane;
71
72 lane_align = dp_link_status(link_status,
73 DP_LANE_ALIGN_STATUS_UPDATED);
74 if ((lane_align & DP_INTERLANE_ALIGN_DONE) == 0)
75 return false;
76 for (lane = 0; lane < lane_count; lane++) {
77 lane_status = dp_get_lane_status(link_status, lane);
78 if ((lane_status & DP_CHANNEL_EQ_BITS) != DP_CHANNEL_EQ_BITS)
79 return false;
80 }
81 return true;
82}
83EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_channel_eq_ok);
84
85bool drm_dp_clock_recovery_ok(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE],
86 int lane_count)
87{
88 int lane;
89 u8 lane_status;
90
91 for (lane = 0; lane < lane_count; lane++) {
92 lane_status = dp_get_lane_status(link_status, lane);
93 if ((lane_status & DP_LANE_CR_DONE) == 0)
94 return false;
95 }
96 return true;
97}
98EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_clock_recovery_ok);
99
100u8 drm_dp_get_adjust_request_voltage(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE],
101 int lane)
102{
103 int i = DP_ADJUST_REQUEST_LANE0_1 + (lane >> 1);
104 int s = ((lane & 1) ?
105 DP_ADJUST_VOLTAGE_SWING_LANE1_SHIFT :
106 DP_ADJUST_VOLTAGE_SWING_LANE0_SHIFT);
107 u8 l = dp_link_status(link_status, i);
108
109 return ((l >> s) & 0x3) << DP_TRAIN_VOLTAGE_SWING_SHIFT;
110}
111EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_get_adjust_request_voltage);
112
113u8 drm_dp_get_adjust_request_pre_emphasis(const u8 link_status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE],
114 int lane)
115{
116 int i = DP_ADJUST_REQUEST_LANE0_1 + (lane >> 1);
117 int s = ((lane & 1) ?
118 DP_ADJUST_PRE_EMPHASIS_LANE1_SHIFT :
119 DP_ADJUST_PRE_EMPHASIS_LANE0_SHIFT);
120 u8 l = dp_link_status(link_status, i);
121
122 return ((l >> s) & 0x3) << DP_TRAIN_PRE_EMPHASIS_SHIFT;
123}
124EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_get_adjust_request_pre_emphasis);
125
126void drm_dp_link_train_clock_recovery_delay(const u8 dpcd[DP_RECEIVER_CAP_SIZE]) {
127 if (dpcd[DP_TRAINING_AUX_RD_INTERVAL] == 0)
128 udelay(100);
129 else
130 mdelay(dpcd[DP_TRAINING_AUX_RD_INTERVAL] * 4);
131}
132EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_train_clock_recovery_delay);
133
134void drm_dp_link_train_channel_eq_delay(const u8 dpcd[DP_RECEIVER_CAP_SIZE]) {
135 if (dpcd[DP_TRAINING_AUX_RD_INTERVAL] == 0)
136 udelay(400);
137 else
138 mdelay(dpcd[DP_TRAINING_AUX_RD_INTERVAL] * 4);
139}
140EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_train_channel_eq_delay);
141
142u8 drm_dp_link_rate_to_bw_code(int link_rate)
143{
144 switch (link_rate) {
145 case 162000:
146 default:
147 return DP_LINK_BW_1_62;
148 case 270000:
149 return DP_LINK_BW_2_7;
150 case 540000:
151 return DP_LINK_BW_5_4;
152 }
153}
154EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_rate_to_bw_code);
155
156int drm_dp_bw_code_to_link_rate(u8 link_bw)
157{
158 switch (link_bw) {
159 case DP_LINK_BW_1_62:
160 default:
161 return 162000;
162 case DP_LINK_BW_2_7:
163 return 270000;
164 case DP_LINK_BW_5_4:
165 return 540000;
166 }
167}
168EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_bw_code_to_link_rate);
169
170#define AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL 500 /* us */
171
172/**
173 * DOC: dp helpers
174 *
175 * The DisplayPort AUX channel is an abstraction to allow generic, driver-
176 * independent access to AUX functionality. Drivers can take advantage of
177 * this by filling in the fields of the drm_dp_aux structure.
178 *
179 * Transactions are described using a hardware-independent drm_dp_aux_msg
180 * structure, which is passed into a driver's .transfer() implementation.
181 * Both native and I2C-over-AUX transactions are supported.
182 */
183
184static int drm_dp_dpcd_access(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, u8 request,
185 unsigned int offset, void *buffer, size_t size)
186{
187 struct drm_dp_aux_msg msg;
188 unsigned int retry;
189 int err = 0;
190
191 memset(&msg, 0, sizeof(msg));
192 msg.address = offset;
193 msg.request = request;
194 msg.buffer = buffer;
195 msg.size = size;
196
197 mutex_lock(&aux->hw_mutex);
198
199 /*
200 * The specification doesn't give any recommendation on how often to
201 * retry native transactions. We used to retry 7 times like for
202 * aux i2c transactions but real world devices this wasn't
203 * sufficient, bump to 32 which makes Dell 4k monitors happier.
204 */
205 for (retry = 0; retry < 32; retry++) {
206
207 err = aux->transfer(aux, &msg);
208 if (err < 0) {
209 if (err == -EBUSY)
210 continue;
211
212 goto unlock;
213 }
214
215
216 switch (msg.reply & DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_MASK) {
217 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_ACK:
218 if (err < size)
219 err = -EPROTO;
220 goto unlock;
221
222 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_NACK:
223 err = -EIO;
224 goto unlock;
225
226 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_DEFER:
227 usleep_range(AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL, AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL + 100);
228 break;
229 }
230 }
231
232 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("too many retries, giving up\n");
233 err = -EIO;
234
235unlock:
236 mutex_unlock(&aux->hw_mutex);
237 return err;
238}
239
240/**
241 * drm_dp_dpcd_read() - read a series of bytes from the DPCD
242 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
243 * @offset: address of the (first) register to read
244 * @buffer: buffer to store the register values
245 * @size: number of bytes in @buffer
246 *
247 * Returns the number of bytes transferred on success, or a negative error
248 * code on failure. -EIO is returned if the request was NAKed by the sink or
249 * if the retry count was exceeded. If not all bytes were transferred, this
250 * function returns -EPROTO. Errors from the underlying AUX channel transfer
251 * function, with the exception of -EBUSY (which causes the transaction to
252 * be retried), are propagated to the caller.
253 */
254ssize_t drm_dp_dpcd_read(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, unsigned int offset,
255 void *buffer, size_t size)
256{
257 return drm_dp_dpcd_access(aux, DP_AUX_NATIVE_READ, offset, buffer,
258 size);
259}
260EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_dpcd_read);
261
262/**
263 * drm_dp_dpcd_write() - write a series of bytes to the DPCD
264 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
265 * @offset: address of the (first) register to write
266 * @buffer: buffer containing the values to write
267 * @size: number of bytes in @buffer
268 *
269 * Returns the number of bytes transferred on success, or a negative error
270 * code on failure. -EIO is returned if the request was NAKed by the sink or
271 * if the retry count was exceeded. If not all bytes were transferred, this
272 * function returns -EPROTO. Errors from the underlying AUX channel transfer
273 * function, with the exception of -EBUSY (which causes the transaction to
274 * be retried), are propagated to the caller.
275 */
276ssize_t drm_dp_dpcd_write(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, unsigned int offset,
277 void *buffer, size_t size)
278{
279 return drm_dp_dpcd_access(aux, DP_AUX_NATIVE_WRITE, offset, buffer,
280 size);
281}
282EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_dpcd_write);
283
284/**
285 * drm_dp_dpcd_read_link_status() - read DPCD link status (bytes 0x202-0x207)
286 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
287 * @status: buffer to store the link status in (must be at least 6 bytes)
288 *
289 * Returns the number of bytes transferred on success or a negative error
290 * code on failure.
291 */
292int drm_dp_dpcd_read_link_status(struct drm_dp_aux *aux,
293 u8 status[DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE])
294{
295 return drm_dp_dpcd_read(aux, DP_LANE0_1_STATUS, status,
296 DP_LINK_STATUS_SIZE);
297}
298EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_dpcd_read_link_status);
299
300/**
301 * drm_dp_link_probe() - probe a DisplayPort link for capabilities
302 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
303 * @link: pointer to structure in which to return link capabilities
304 *
305 * The structure filled in by this function can usually be passed directly
306 * into drm_dp_link_power_up() and drm_dp_link_configure() to power up and
307 * configure the link based on the link's capabilities.
308 *
309 * Returns 0 on success or a negative error code on failure.
310 */
311int drm_dp_link_probe(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_link *link)
312{
313 u8 values[3];
314 int err;
315
316 memset(link, 0, sizeof(*link));
317
318 err = drm_dp_dpcd_read(aux, DP_DPCD_REV, values, sizeof(values));
319 if (err < 0)
320 return err;
321
322 link->revision = values[0];
323 link->rate = drm_dp_bw_code_to_link_rate(values[1]);
324 link->num_lanes = values[2] & DP_MAX_LANE_COUNT_MASK;
325
326 if (values[2] & DP_ENHANCED_FRAME_CAP)
327 link->capabilities |= DP_LINK_CAP_ENHANCED_FRAMING;
328
329 return 0;
330}
331EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_probe);
332
333/**
334 * drm_dp_link_power_up() - power up a DisplayPort link
335 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
336 * @link: pointer to a structure containing the link configuration
337 *
338 * Returns 0 on success or a negative error code on failure.
339 */
340int drm_dp_link_power_up(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_link *link)
341{
342 u8 value;
343 int err;
344
345 /* DP_SET_POWER register is only available on DPCD v1.1 and later */
346 if (link->revision < 0x11)
347 return 0;
348
349 err = drm_dp_dpcd_readb(aux, DP_SET_POWER, &value);
350 if (err < 0)
351 return err;
352
353 value &= ~DP_SET_POWER_MASK;
354 value |= DP_SET_POWER_D0;
355
356 err = drm_dp_dpcd_writeb(aux, DP_SET_POWER, value);
357 if (err < 0)
358 return err;
359
360 /*
361 * According to the DP 1.1 specification, a "Sink Device must exit the
362 * power saving state within 1 ms" (Section 2.5.3.1, Table 5-52, "Sink
363 * Control Field" (register 0x600).
364 */
365 usleep_range(1000, 2000);
366
367 return 0;
368}
369EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_power_up);
370
371/**
372 * drm_dp_link_power_down() - power down a DisplayPort link
373 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
374 * @link: pointer to a structure containing the link configuration
375 *
376 * Returns 0 on success or a negative error code on failure.
377 */
378int drm_dp_link_power_down(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_link *link)
379{
380 u8 value;
381 int err;
382
383 /* DP_SET_POWER register is only available on DPCD v1.1 and later */
384 if (link->revision < 0x11)
385 return 0;
386
387 err = drm_dp_dpcd_readb(aux, DP_SET_POWER, &value);
388 if (err < 0)
389 return err;
390
391 value &= ~DP_SET_POWER_MASK;
392 value |= DP_SET_POWER_D3;
393
394 err = drm_dp_dpcd_writeb(aux, DP_SET_POWER, value);
395 if (err < 0)
396 return err;
397
398 return 0;
399}
400EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_power_down);
401
402/**
403 * drm_dp_link_configure() - configure a DisplayPort link
404 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
405 * @link: pointer to a structure containing the link configuration
406 *
407 * Returns 0 on success or a negative error code on failure.
408 */
409int drm_dp_link_configure(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_link *link)
410{
411 u8 values[2];
412 int err;
413
414 values[0] = drm_dp_link_rate_to_bw_code(link->rate);
415 values[1] = link->num_lanes;
416
417 if (link->capabilities & DP_LINK_CAP_ENHANCED_FRAMING)
418 values[1] |= DP_LANE_COUNT_ENHANCED_FRAME_EN;
419
420 err = drm_dp_dpcd_write(aux, DP_LINK_BW_SET, values, sizeof(values));
421 if (err < 0)
422 return err;
423
424 return 0;
425}
426EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_link_configure);
427
428/*
429 * I2C-over-AUX implementation
430 */
431
432static u32 drm_dp_i2c_functionality(struct i2c_adapter *adapter)
433{
434 return I2C_FUNC_I2C | I2C_FUNC_SMBUS_EMUL |
435 I2C_FUNC_SMBUS_READ_BLOCK_DATA |
436 I2C_FUNC_SMBUS_BLOCK_PROC_CALL |
437 I2C_FUNC_10BIT_ADDR;
438}
439
440static void drm_dp_i2c_msg_write_status_update(struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg)
441{
442 /*
443 * In case of i2c defer or short i2c ack reply to a write,
444 * we need to switch to WRITE_STATUS_UPDATE to drain the
445 * rest of the message
446 */
447 if ((msg->request & ~DP_AUX_I2C_MOT) == DP_AUX_I2C_WRITE) {
448 msg->request &= DP_AUX_I2C_MOT;
449 msg->request |= DP_AUX_I2C_WRITE_STATUS_UPDATE;
450 }
451}
452
453#define AUX_PRECHARGE_LEN 10 /* 10 to 16 */
454#define AUX_SYNC_LEN (16 + 4) /* preamble + AUX_SYNC_END */
455#define AUX_STOP_LEN 4
456#define AUX_CMD_LEN 4
457#define AUX_ADDRESS_LEN 20
458#define AUX_REPLY_PAD_LEN 4
459#define AUX_LENGTH_LEN 8
460
461/*
462 * Calculate the duration of the AUX request/reply in usec. Gives the
463 * "best" case estimate, ie. successful while as short as possible.
464 */
465static int drm_dp_aux_req_duration(const struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg)
466{
467 int len = AUX_PRECHARGE_LEN + AUX_SYNC_LEN + AUX_STOP_LEN +
468 AUX_CMD_LEN + AUX_ADDRESS_LEN + AUX_LENGTH_LEN;
469
470 if ((msg->request & DP_AUX_I2C_READ) == 0)
471 len += msg->size * 8;
472
473 return len;
474}
475
476static int drm_dp_aux_reply_duration(const struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg)
477{
478 int len = AUX_PRECHARGE_LEN + AUX_SYNC_LEN + AUX_STOP_LEN +
479 AUX_CMD_LEN + AUX_REPLY_PAD_LEN;
480
481 /*
482 * For read we expect what was asked. For writes there will
483 * be 0 or 1 data bytes. Assume 0 for the "best" case.
484 */
485 if (msg->request & DP_AUX_I2C_READ)
486 len += msg->size * 8;
487
488 return len;
489}
490
491#define I2C_START_LEN 1
492#define I2C_STOP_LEN 1
493#define I2C_ADDR_LEN 9 /* ADDRESS + R/W + ACK/NACK */
494#define I2C_DATA_LEN 9 /* DATA + ACK/NACK */
495
496/*
497 * Calculate the length of the i2c transfer in usec, assuming
498 * the i2c bus speed is as specified. Gives the the "worst"
499 * case estimate, ie. successful while as long as possible.
500 * Doesn't account the the "MOT" bit, and instead assumes each
501 * message includes a START, ADDRESS and STOP. Neither does it
502 * account for additional random variables such as clock stretching.
503 */
504static int drm_dp_i2c_msg_duration(const struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg,
505 int i2c_speed_khz)
506{
507 /* AUX bitrate is 1MHz, i2c bitrate as specified */
508 return DIV_ROUND_UP((I2C_START_LEN + I2C_ADDR_LEN +
509 msg->size * I2C_DATA_LEN +
510 I2C_STOP_LEN) * 1000, i2c_speed_khz);
511}
512
513/*
514 * Deterine how many retries should be attempted to successfully transfer
515 * the specified message, based on the estimated durations of the
516 * i2c and AUX transfers.
517 */
518static int drm_dp_i2c_retry_count(const struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg,
519 int i2c_speed_khz)
520{
521 int aux_time_us = drm_dp_aux_req_duration(msg) +
522 drm_dp_aux_reply_duration(msg);
523 int i2c_time_us = drm_dp_i2c_msg_duration(msg, i2c_speed_khz);
524
525 return DIV_ROUND_UP(i2c_time_us, aux_time_us + AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL);
526}
527
528/*
529 * FIXME currently assumes 10 kHz as some real world devices seem
530 * to require it. We should query/set the speed via DPCD if supported.
531 */
532static int dp_aux_i2c_speed_khz __read_mostly = 10;
533module_param_unsafe(dp_aux_i2c_speed_khz, int, 0644);
534MODULE_PARM_DESC(dp_aux_i2c_speed_khz,
535 "Assumed speed of the i2c bus in kHz, (1-400, default 10)");
536
537/*
538 * Transfer a single I2C-over-AUX message and handle various error conditions,
539 * retrying the transaction as appropriate. It is assumed that the
540 * aux->transfer function does not modify anything in the msg other than the
541 * reply field.
542 *
543 * Returns bytes transferred on success, or a negative error code on failure.
544 */
545static int drm_dp_i2c_do_msg(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg)
546{
547 unsigned int retry, defer_i2c;
548 int ret;
549 /*
550 * DP1.2 sections 2.7.7.1.5.6.1 and 2.7.7.1.6.6.1: A DP Source device
551 * is required to retry at least seven times upon receiving AUX_DEFER
552 * before giving up the AUX transaction.
553 *
554 * We also try to account for the i2c bus speed.
555 */
556 int max_retries = max(7, drm_dp_i2c_retry_count(msg, dp_aux_i2c_speed_khz));
557
558 for (retry = 0, defer_i2c = 0; retry < (max_retries + defer_i2c); retry++) {
559 ret = aux->transfer(aux, msg);
560 if (ret < 0) {
561 if (ret == -EBUSY)
562 continue;
563
564 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("transaction failed: %d\n", ret);
565 return ret;
566 }
567
568
569 switch (msg->reply & DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_MASK) {
570 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_ACK:
571 /*
572 * For I2C-over-AUX transactions this isn't enough, we
573 * need to check for the I2C ACK reply.
574 */
575 break;
576
577 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_NACK:
578 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("native nack (result=%d, size=%zu)\n", ret, msg->size);
579 return -EREMOTEIO;
580
581 case DP_AUX_NATIVE_REPLY_DEFER:
582 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("native defer\n");
583 /*
584 * We could check for I2C bit rate capabilities and if
585 * available adjust this interval. We could also be
586 * more careful with DP-to-legacy adapters where a
587 * long legacy cable may force very low I2C bit rates.
588 *
589 * For now just defer for long enough to hopefully be
590 * safe for all use-cases.
591 */
592 usleep_range(AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL, AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL + 100);
593 continue;
594
595 default:
596 DRM_ERROR("invalid native reply %#04x\n", msg->reply);
597 return -EREMOTEIO;
598 }
599
600 switch (msg->reply & DP_AUX_I2C_REPLY_MASK) {
601 case DP_AUX_I2C_REPLY_ACK:
602 /*
603 * Both native ACK and I2C ACK replies received. We
604 * can assume the transfer was successful.
605 */
606 if (ret != msg->size)
607 drm_dp_i2c_msg_write_status_update(msg);
608 return ret;
609
610 case DP_AUX_I2C_REPLY_NACK:
611 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("I2C nack (result=%d, size=%zu\n", ret, msg->size);
612 aux->i2c_nack_count++;
613 return -EREMOTEIO;
614
615 case DP_AUX_I2C_REPLY_DEFER:
616 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("I2C defer\n");
617 /* DP Compliance Test 4.2.2.5 Requirement:
618 * Must have at least 7 retries for I2C defers on the
619 * transaction to pass this test
620 */
621 aux->i2c_defer_count++;
622 if (defer_i2c < 7)
623 defer_i2c++;
624 usleep_range(AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL, AUX_RETRY_INTERVAL + 100);
625 drm_dp_i2c_msg_write_status_update(msg);
626
627 continue;
628
629 default:
630 DRM_ERROR("invalid I2C reply %#04x\n", msg->reply);
631 return -EREMOTEIO;
632 }
633 }
634
635 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("too many retries, giving up\n");
636 return -EREMOTEIO;
637}
638
639static void drm_dp_i2c_msg_set_request(struct drm_dp_aux_msg *msg,
640 const struct i2c_msg *i2c_msg)
641{
642 msg->request = (i2c_msg->flags & I2C_M_RD) ?
643 DP_AUX_I2C_READ : DP_AUX_I2C_WRITE;
644 msg->request |= DP_AUX_I2C_MOT;
645}
646
647/*
648 * Keep retrying drm_dp_i2c_do_msg until all data has been transferred.
649 *
650 * Returns an error code on failure, or a recommended transfer size on success.
651 */
652static int drm_dp_i2c_drain_msg(struct drm_dp_aux *aux, struct drm_dp_aux_msg *orig_msg)
653{
654 int err, ret = orig_msg->size;
655 struct drm_dp_aux_msg msg = *orig_msg;
656
657 while (msg.size > 0) {
658 err = drm_dp_i2c_do_msg(aux, &msg);
659 if (err <= 0)
660 return err == 0 ? -EPROTO : err;
661
662 if (err < msg.size && err < ret) {
663 DRM_DEBUG_KMS("Partial I2C reply: requested %zu bytes got %d bytes\n",
664 msg.size, err);
665 ret = err;
666 }
667
668 msg.size -= err;
669 msg.buffer = (void *)((char *)msg.buffer + err);
670 }
671
672 return ret;
673}
674
675/*
676 * Bizlink designed DP->DVI-D Dual Link adapters require the I2C over AUX
677 * packets to be as large as possible. If not, the I2C transactions never
678 * succeed. Hence the default is maximum.
679 */
680static int dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size __read_mostly = DP_AUX_MAX_PAYLOAD_BYTES;
681module_param_unsafe(dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size, int, 0644);
682MODULE_PARM_DESC(dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size,
683 "Number of bytes to transfer in a single I2C over DP AUX CH message, (1-16, default 16)");
684
685static int drm_dp_i2c_xfer(struct i2c_adapter *adapter, struct i2c_msg *msgs,
686 int num)
687{
688 struct drm_dp_aux *aux = adapter->algo_data;
689 unsigned int i, j;
690 unsigned transfer_size;
691 struct drm_dp_aux_msg msg;
692 int err = 0;
693
694 dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size = clamp(dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size, 1, DP_AUX_MAX_PAYLOAD_BYTES);
695
696 memset(&msg, 0, sizeof(msg));
697
698 mutex_lock(&aux->hw_mutex);
699
700 for (i = 0; i < num; i++) {
701 msg.address = msgs[i].addr;
702 drm_dp_i2c_msg_set_request(&msg, &msgs[i]);
703 /* Send a bare address packet to start the transaction.
704 * Zero sized messages specify an address only (bare
705 * address) transaction.
706 */
707 msg.buffer = NULL;
708 msg.size = 0;
709 err = drm_dp_i2c_do_msg(aux, &msg);
710
711 /*
712 * Reset msg.request in case in case it got
713 * changed into a WRITE_STATUS_UPDATE.
714 */
715 drm_dp_i2c_msg_set_request(&msg, &msgs[i]);
716
717 if (err < 0)
718 break;
719 /* We want each transaction to be as large as possible, but
720 * we'll go to smaller sizes if the hardware gives us a
721 * short reply.
722 */
723 transfer_size = dp_aux_i2c_transfer_size;
724 for (j = 0; j < msgs[i].len; j += msg.size) {
725 msg.buffer = msgs[i].buf + j;
726 msg.size = min(transfer_size, msgs[i].len - j);
727
728 err = drm_dp_i2c_drain_msg(aux, &msg);
729
730 /*
731 * Reset msg.request in case in case it got
732 * changed into a WRITE_STATUS_UPDATE.
733 */
734 drm_dp_i2c_msg_set_request(&msg, &msgs[i]);
735
736 if (err < 0)
737 break;
738 transfer_size = err;
739 }
740 if (err < 0)
741 break;
742 }
743 if (err >= 0)
744 err = num;
745 /* Send a bare address packet to close out the transaction.
746 * Zero sized messages specify an address only (bare
747 * address) transaction.
748 */
749 msg.request &= ~DP_AUX_I2C_MOT;
750 msg.buffer = NULL;
751 msg.size = 0;
752 (void)drm_dp_i2c_do_msg(aux, &msg);
753
754 mutex_unlock(&aux->hw_mutex);
755
756 return err;
757}
758
759static const struct i2c_algorithm drm_dp_i2c_algo = {
760 .functionality = drm_dp_i2c_functionality,
761 .master_xfer = drm_dp_i2c_xfer,
762};
763
764/**
765 * drm_dp_aux_register() - initialise and register aux channel
766 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
767 *
768 * Returns 0 on success or a negative error code on failure.
769 */
770int drm_dp_aux_register(struct drm_dp_aux *aux)
771{
772#ifdef __NetBSD__
773 linux_mutex_init(&aux->hw_mutex);
774#else
775 mutex_init(&aux->hw_mutex);
776#endif
777
778 aux->ddc.algo = &drm_dp_i2c_algo;
779 aux->ddc.algo_data = aux;
780 aux->ddc.retries = 3;
781
782 aux->ddc.class = I2C_CLASS_DDC;
783 aux->ddc.owner = THIS_MODULE;
784 aux->ddc.dev.parent = aux->dev;
785#ifndef __NetBSD__
786 aux->ddc.dev.of_node = aux->dev->of_node;
787#endif
788
789 strlcpy(aux->ddc.name, aux->name ? aux->name : dev_name(aux->dev),
790 sizeof(aux->ddc.name));
791
792 return i2c_add_adapter(&aux->ddc);
793}
794EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_aux_register);
795
796/**
797 * drm_dp_aux_unregister() - unregister an AUX adapter
798 * @aux: DisplayPort AUX channel
799 */
800void drm_dp_aux_unregister(struct drm_dp_aux *aux)
801{
802 i2c_del_adapter(&aux->ddc);
803#ifdef __NetBSD__
804 linux_mutex_destroy(&aux->hw_mutex);
805#else
806 mutex_destroy(&aux->hw_mutex);
807#endif
808}
809EXPORT_SYMBOL(drm_dp_aux_unregister);
